name: Introductory Cultural Anthropology (GT-SS3)
description: Course Description: Human societies and their cultural setting; variation in beliefs, social customs, and technologies; human differences in anthropological terms.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column10: Additional Information:  Social & Behavioral Sciences 3C, Human Behavior, Culture, or Social Frameworks (GT-SS3).
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Practicing Anthropology  Credit
description: Course Description: Familiarizes majors with the sub-fields of anthropology and provides an overview via practical exercises of foundational skills necessary for success in the anthropology major, CSU, and beyond. Topics include critical thinking and writing, conducting research, scholarly communication, and professional career development, with attention to how these apply to anthropology in particular.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Registration Information: Anthropology majors only. Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Human Origins and Variation (GT-SC2)
description: Course Description: Mechanisms of evolution; genetics. Living primate biology, behavior, and history. Human evolutionary history. Human variation and adaptation.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column10: Additional Information:  Biological & Physical Sciences 3A, Natural & Physical Sciences w/o lab (GT-SC2).
column11: Registration Information: Mixed face-to-face is a partial semester course. Sections may be offered: Online. Credit not allowed for both ANTH 180A1 and ANTH 120.

name: Human Origins and Variation Laboratory (GT-SC1)  Credit
description: Course Description: Labs demonstrating genetic and evolutionary processes, comparative skeletal anatomy, human evolution through fossil casts, and modern human variation.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120, may be taken concurrently.
column10: Additional Information:  Biological & Physical Sciences 3A, Natural & Physical Sciences w/ lab (GT-SC1).
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Introduction to Archaeology (GT-HI1)
description: Course Description: Origins of human society from the Stone Age to urban civilization using architecture, art, tools, and other material remains.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Imagining Sustainability
description: Course Description: Science alone cannot imagine the revolutionary changes necessary to sustain future life on our planet. Explore key concepts and practices of sustainability as represented in contemporary fiction, film, and the news media. Interdisciplinary approach will be anthropological and historical, charting the development of sustainability thinking through different epochs of capitalism.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Also Offered As:  ESS 150.
column12: Registration Information: Credit allowed for only one of the following: ANTH 150, ANTH 181A1, ESS 150, or ESS 181A1.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Cultures and the Global System (GT-SS3)
description: Course Description: Analyze diversity of smaller-scale societies, and cultural responses and adaptations to emerging global trends.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column10: Additional Information:  Diversity, Equity, & Inclusion 1C, Human Behavior, Culture, or Social Frameworks (GT-SS3).
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Anthropology of the Arts
description: Course Description: Explores the arts (both visual and performing) from the perspective of cultural anthropology. What is art and how is the category differently constructed cross-culturally? Why and how do people make, consume, and identify with expressive culture? How can the visual and performing arts help us to develop a deeper understanding of how human beings make meaning? Read a variety of ethnographic texts that illuminate these and related questions.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).

name: Soundscapes-Music as Human Practice
description: Course Description: Musical communities and soundscapes from around the world provide exploration points for how music and sound inform human life. Study everything from playlists to music of distant lands. Ability to read notated music not required.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Also Offered As:  MU 232.
column12: Registration Information: Previous music experience not required. Credit allowed for only one of the following: ANTH 232, MU 232, or MU 280A2.

name: Indigenous Peoples of North America
description: Course Description: Explores Native groups of North America from an anthropological perspective, and utilizes a culture area framework as a basis for investigation. Culture area framework is largely based on historical material–how these people have lived in the recent past. Evaluating how these groups live in the present. Contemporary issues, globalization, and local responses to local concerns.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online. Credit not allowed for both ANTH 235 and ANTH 280A2.

name: Museum and Cultural Heritage Studies
description: Course Description: Introduction to basic theory and organization of museums and cultural heritage sites including their history, their role in society as places of preservation and education, exhibitions and interpretation, and the relationship between museums and cultural heritage sites and the communities they serve. Emphasis on defining the role of anthropology in today’s museums and cultural heritage sites and multidisciplinary approaches to curation.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Registration Information: Required field trips. Sections may be offered: Online. Credit not allowed for both ANTH 240 and ANTH 281A2.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Introduction to Field Archaeology
description: Course Description: Field methods including map preparation and interpretation, site location and recording, site excavation, and stratigraphy.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.
column11: Registration Information: Must register for lecture and laboratory.Term Offered: Summer.

name: Human Diversity (GT-SC2)
description: Course Description: Explore human diversity, both physical and genetic, within an evolutionary framework. The scientific method is applied to the sociocultural contexts that give rise to prejudices in order to critically evaluate misconceptions regarding race, gender, and human behaviors deemed 'natural’. Approaching human diversity from an evolutionary perspective dismantles biases that justify prejudice and result in unequal access to power and resources as well as negative health impacts.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column10: Additional Information:  Biological & Physical Sciences 3A, Natural & Physical Sciences w/o lab (GT-SC2).

name: Introduction to Forensic Anthropology
description: Course Description: Forensic anthropological theory and methods including estimation of age-at-death, sex, stature, ancestry, and trauma analysis.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Also Offered As:  SOC 275.
column12: Registration Information: Credit not allowed for both ANTH 275 and SOC 275. Sections may be offered: Online.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Independent Study
description: Course Description:
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.

name: Peoples and Cultures of Africa
description: Course Description: Sub-Saharan lifestyles including marriage and family, traditional government, religion and magic, ecology and economy, art, music, and literature.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100.Term Offered: Spring (even years).
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Modern Indian Culture and Society
description: Course Description: Anthropological contributions to the understanding of contemporary India.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.Term Offered: Spring (odd years).
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Modernization and Development
description: Course Description: Processes by which cultures change and modernize, 1989 to the present.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Southeast Asian Cultures and Societies
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.

name: Global Mobilities–The African Diaspora
description: Course Description: Globalization and transnationalism with a focus on the circulation of people, ideas, and cultural products and practices between Africa and the rest of the world. By situating Africans as both producers and consumers of transnational ideas and products, we will develop an understanding of Africa beyond popular representations of violence and crisis.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200 or GR 100 or SOC 100.
column11: Registration Information: Junior standing.Term Offered: Spring (odd years).

name: Anthropology of Human Rights
description: Course Description: Human rights from the perspective of cultural anthropology through its theoretical and practical dimensions. Contemporary human rights debates within the context of cultural plurality in a globalized world. Engages the intersection between global dynamics and community experiences by addressing the human rights dimensions of refugees and migration, indigenous communities, women and children, health, religious practices, among others.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Offered as an online course only.

name: The Anthropology of Religion
description: Course Description: Major anthropological theories and descriptions of religious beliefs and practices. Religion in a cross-cultural and evolutionary perspective.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).

name: Cultural Change
description: Course Description: Cultural change and effects of directed global forces; colonial origins of underdevelopment on small-scale societies.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Human Ecology
description: Course Description: Roles of technology, economics, social organization, and ideology in human adaptations to and survival in natural and cultural environments.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  (ANTH 100 or ANTH 200) and (ANTH 120 or BZ 101 or LAND 220 or LIFE 220).
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.Term Offered: Fall (even years).

name: Anthropology of Sex and Reproduction
description: Course Description: Contemporary scholarship on issues in the anthropology of reproduction, including the relationship between production and reproduction and between the corporeal body and the body politic, the disciplinary power of the state, public controversies such as abortion and maternal-fetal conflict, and the symbolism and metaphors of procreation and parenthood. We will use "reproduction" as an analytic strategy to shed light on the cultural politics of gender, power, and sexuality.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Sophomore standing. Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Narrative Traditions and Social Experience
description: Course Description: Relationship between narrative traditions and social contexts of their creation.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200 or E 140 or SOC 100.Term Offered: Spring (even years).

name: Language and Culture
description: Course Description: Human language and primate communication, nonverbal channels, sociolinguistics, and language change.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Art and Culture
description: Course Description: Art expression is a defining factor in cultural identity and representation in a modern world where geographical and political borders are diminishing.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200. Restriction: .
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Gender and Anthropology
description: Course Description: Theory, themes, and debates in anthropological gender studies, ethnographic survey of women and men cross-culturally.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.Term Offered: Spring (odd years).

name: Medical Anthropology
description: Course Description: Cultural adaptation to disease; non-Western theories of health and disease; categories, causes, cures; learned roles of patients and healers.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Applied Medical Anthropology
description: Course Description: How and why we get sick and what sickness means from biological, social and cultural perspectives.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Archaeology of North America
description: Course Description: Native American life, tools, architecture, religion, food-getting from cultures of 12,000 years ago or earlier until European contact.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Archaeology of Europe and Africa
description: Course Description: Human culture, tools, art, religion, social life, subsistence, and paleoecology from 4 million B.C. to 1200 B.C. in the Old World.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.Term Offered: Spring (even years).
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Geoarchaeology
description: Course Description: Analytical techniques, concepts, and field methodologies from the earth sciences to better understand the archaeological record.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.Term Offered: Spring.

name: Archaeology of Rock Art
description: Course Description: Study of prehistoric and recent rock art worldwide from an anthropological and cross-cultural perspective. Provide a strong understanding of what rock art is, how it is recorded, analyzed, and interpreted by archaeologists, and why ancient symbolism and sites are considered important in contemporary society.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Registration Information: Sophomore standing. Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Race/Ethnicity in the Ancient Mediterranean
description: Course Description: Archaeology of the Ancient Mediterranean (specifically Greek and Roman) World as related to race and ethnicity. Examination of how some ancients created their own ethnographical identities and thought through conceptions of ancient races/peoples, and how this world has been appropriated by western European countries, been used as an emblem of whiteness, and served as a pretext for justifying racism today.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Archaeology of the Ancient Nile
description: Course Description: Explore the broad anthropological trends of the archaeology of the Ancient Nile (specifically Egypt and Kush/Nubia). Approaches this world via important archaeological topics and trends that contextualize the historical and socio-political trends, influences, and impetuses to come to a holistic understanding of what it meant to be an ancient Egyptian or Kushite from c. 5000 BCE to the end of Roman Rule in c. 400 CE.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.
column11: Registration Information: Offered as an online course only.

name: Archaeologies of Graffiti
description: Course Description: An in-depth examination of graffiti as a human social behavior and form of material culture in the past and present. Examines the form, function, and context of graffiti across cultures and through time, with regard to the circumstances of its creation. Addresses what lies behind the human urge to leave a mark.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 120 or ANTH 140 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.Term Offered: Spring (odd years).

name: Colorado Prehistory
description: Course Description: Human behavioral responses to environmental diversity, cultural adaptation, Pleistocene and recent climates, anthropogenic environmental change.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.
column11: Registration Information: Must register for lecture and recitation.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Archaeological Investigation
description: Course Description: Investigation of the archaeological record, how the record was formed, and how archaeological data are analyzed and interpreted.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.Term Offered: Spring.

name: Quantifying Anthropology
description: Course Description: Managing, quantifying and illustrating anthropological data-sets with appropriate software.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 120 or ANTH 140 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.Term Offered: Spring.

name: Primates
description: Course Description: Behavioral patterns, ecological relationships, and communication of nonhuman primates.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 101.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Growing Up Primate
description: Course Description: Primates generally have extended periods of growth compared to other mammals; however, there is considerable variation across the Primate Order. Evolution of primate growth and reproductive strategies, critically evaluates current models of life history variation, examines the ways that primate taxa negotiate trade offs (e.g. current versus future reproduction), and explains the role of human sociality in the evolution of our unique life history parameters.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 101.
column11: Registration Information: Junior standing.Term Offered: Spring (even years).

name: Human Osteology
description: Course Description: Human bones and teeth in a review of functional human evolution.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 101 or BZ 110 or LIFE 102.
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.
column11: Registration Information: Must register for lecture and laboratory.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Human Evolution
description: Course Description: Current topics and debates in human evolution concentrating on biocultural changes in the human lineage.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 110.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Human Biological Variation
description: Course Description: Biological diversity of human populations; history of development of race concept.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 101 or BZ 110 or LIFE 102.
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.
column11: Registration Information: Must register for lecture and recitation. Sections may be offered: Online.Term Offered: Spring (even years).

name: Evolution of Primate Behavior
description: Course Description: Primate behavior from an evolutionary perspective, drawing on a variety of studies of humans, primates, and mammals.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 110 or LIFE 102.
column11: Registration Information: Junior standing. Sections may be offered: Online.Term Offered: Spring (odd years).

name: Evolution of Human Adaptation
description: Course Description: Unique characteristics of humans: bipedalism, encephalization, dentition, birth process, an attenuated period of development.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 110 or LIFE 102.
column11: Registration Information: Must register for lecture and recitation.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Anthropology Perspectives-Evolution, Society
description: Course Description: Evolutionary science in educating the public is investigated and anthropological knowledge of human evolutionary biology is examined.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120.
column11: Registration Information: Credit not allowed for both ANTH 377 and ANTH 380A2.

name: Bipedal Apes
description: Course Description: Human bipedal walking within a comparative framework of primate locomotion and anatomy. Specific focus is on kinematics and kinetics of soft- and hard-tissues including analysis of extant primate locomotion, morphology, and development. Discussions focus on debates in primate functional anatomy and locomotion including hypotheses surrounding the origins and evolution bipedal walking and running and possible maladaptations of being a human biped.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 101.
column11: Registration Information: Junior standing.Term Offered: Spring (even years).

name: Evolutionary Medicine and Human Health
description: Course Description: Evolutionary medicine refers to the application of evolutionary theory to the study of human health, disease, and modern medicine. This theoretical perspective provides a deeper lens with which to investigate health, moves us beyond mechanistic explanations of disease, and constructs an anthropological framework for interpreting the evolution of human physiological diversity.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 101 or BZ 110 or LIFE 102.
column11: Registration Information: Sophomore standing.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).

name: A  Study Abroad--Pompeii Italy: Life and Death of a Roman City
description: Course Description: Develop an understanding of Roman cultural, economic, and social history through archaeological analysis of Pompeii and Herculaneum in Italy.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 to 499 - at least 3 credits or ART 100 to 499 - at least 3 credits or HIST 100 to 499 - at least 3 credits or INST 100 to 499 - at least 3 credits or SOC 100 to 499 - at least 3 credits.
column11: Registration Information: Written consent of instructor. Sections offered as Mixed Face-to-Face.Term Offered: Spring.

name: F  Study Abroad--England: Edge of Empire
description: Course Description: Develop an understanding of Roman cultural and military history through archaeological analysis of Hadrian's Wall in England.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 160 to 479 - at least 3 credits or HIST 100 to 479 - at least 3 credits.
column11: Also Offered As:  HIST 382F.
column12: Registration Information: Written consent of instructor. Sections offered as Mixed Face-to-Face or Online. Credit not allowed for both ANTH 382F and HIST 382F.Term Offered: Summer.

name: History of Theory-Anthropology and Geography
description: Course Description: Anthropological/Geographical theory from its beginnings with Aristotle through recent developments into the 20th century.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  (ANTH 100 or ANTH 200) and (ANTH 140 and ANTH 120 and ANTH 121 or GR 100).
column11: Also Offered As:  GR 400.
column12: Registration Information: Junior or senior standing. Sections may be offered: Online. Credit not allowed for both ANTH 400 and GR 400.

name: Psychological Anthropology Laboratory  Credit
description: Course Description: Practical research techniques drawn from psychological and cognitive anthropology for investigating the relationship between shared group culture and individual thought and practice. Mixed qualitative and quantitative methods, including using field observations, interviews, and surveys to illuminate "cultural domains" of thought. Emphasis on collaborative group research and hands-on training involving actual field research and data collection and analysis via appropriate software packages.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 322, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 423, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 444, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 445, may be taken concurrently.
column11: Registration Information: Junior standing. Repeatable for credit.

name: Public Anthropology and Global Challenges
description: Course Description: Value of taking scholarship to the communities. Public scholarship is pointed at many publics and intended to engage actively in the process of solving urgent problems in contrast to traditional scholarship. Focus on the public discourse that addresses disasters, climate change, and global health issues. Critical look at how academic knowledge in these realms serves the public interest.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 300 to 499 - at least 3 credits or SOC 300 to 499 - at least 3 credits.
column11: Registration Information: Junior standing.Term Offered: Spring.

name: Indians of South America
description: Course Description: Ethnographic and cultural characteristics of South American indigenous groups and the current critical issues they face.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200 or ANTH 413 or ANTH 414 or ETST 414.
column11: Registration Information: Offered as an online course only.

name: Indians of North America
description: Course Description: Native American peoples, their cultural variation across the continent, and cultural encounters with colonial expansion.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200 or ANTH 413 or ANTH 414 or ETST 414.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Indigenous Peoples Today
description: Course Description: Contemporary cultural and social issues of indigenous peoples around the globe, including North and South American Indians and Australian Aborigines.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 200 or ANTH 412 or ANTH 414 or ETST 414.Term Offered: Fall.
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Development in Indian Country
description: Course Description: Critical examination of history, public policy, and tribal strategies for economic development and natural resource management in Indian country.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200 or ETST 100.
column11: Also Offered As:  ETST 414.
column12: Registration Information: Credit not allowed for both ANTH 414 and ETST 414.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).

name: Indigenous Ecologies and the Modern World
description: Course Description: Impact of the modern world in indigenous peoples' relationship to their environments and natural resources.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Gender, Culture, and Health
description: Course Description: Examine the role of anthropology in current global health issues paying particular attention to culture and gender.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Indigenous Environmental Stewardship
description: Course Description: Sustainability and environmental stewardship are not necessarily modern day concepts. Indigenous peoples of North America have established traditions and beliefs about harmony and kinship with nature. Focus upon stories and belief systems and their influence upon culture, economics, politics, American history, environmental justice and law.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.Term Offered: Spring.

name: Digital Digging--Geophysics in Archaeology
description: Course Description: Introduction to the geophysical methods archaeologists use to prospect for new sites, and develop new questions for known sites. Examines how common geophysical methods work to detect subsurface signatures for human activity. Provides hands-on experience in data collection, processing, and analysis for multiple instruments. Presents diverse theoretical perspectives from the social sciences that can be applied to interpret subsurface spatial signatures at archaeological sites.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 120 or ANTH 140 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Sophomore standing.Term Offered: Fall (even years).

name: Comparative Legal Systems
description: Course Description: Traditional approaches to law, competing concepts of law in the global system, and experiences of minorities in state legal systems.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or SOC 100.
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.
column11: Also Offered As:  SOC 422.
column12: Registration Information: Credit not allowed for both ANTH 422 and SOC 422.Term Offered: Spring (even years).

name: Cultural Psychiatry
description: Course Description: Social determinants of mental health. Cross-cultural health and healing. Cultural contexts of U.S./Western and Indigenous/non-Western psychiatries.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.Term Offered: Fall (even years).

name: A  Study Abroad--South Africa: Communities and Conservation
description: Course Description: Travel the wildest areas of savanna South Africa to work with and learn from rural and urbanizing communities, offering insights into the innovative forms of community-based natural resource management emerging in South Africa. Understand the new landscapes of conservation associated with post-apartheid South Africa; explore the problems faced by the people living in poverty on the edge of protected areas.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Also Offered As:  ESS 430A.
column12: Registration Information: Sophomore standing. Written consent of instructor. Credit allowed for only one of the following: ANTH 430A, ANTH 482A, ESS 430A, or ESS 482A.Term Offered: Summer.

name: Approaches to Community-Based Development
description: Course Description: Explores the structure and practice of community development globally, engaging in critical analysis of different approaches and their impact.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Offered as an online course only.

name: Community Mobilization
description: Course Description: Structural, social, and psychological barriers that inhibit cooperation and collective action.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Offered as an online course only.

name: Theory in Cultural Anthropology
description: Course Description: Theoretical paradigms used to explain culture including evolutionary, functional, ecological, political economy, postmodernism, and hegemony.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Method in Cultural Anthropology
description: Course Description: Methodological orientations and research techniques. Ethnographic and cross-cultural approaches including quantitative and formal models.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.Term Offered: Spring (odd years).
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Ethnographic Field School
description: Course Description: Directed fieldwork with American Indian communities; methodology, protocols, and social relations of ethnographic field research.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200 or ANTH 100 to 99999 - at least 9 credits.
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.
column11: Registration Information: Required field trips.Term Offered: Summer.

name: Ethnographic Field Methods
description: Course Description: Directed experiential preparation for applied ethnographic field methods and research questions.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.Term Offered: Spring.

name: Cultures of Virtual Worlds–Research Methods
description: Course Description: Methodologies and directed research related to virtual worlds and internet, gaming, play, and fan communities.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Junior standing.Term Offered: Fall (even years).

name: Psychological Anthropology
description: Course Description: Cross-cultural exploration of the human mind by studying the ideas, desires, and practices of individuals in various sociocultural settings.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.Term Offered: Spring (odd years).

name: New Orleans and the Caribbean
description: Course Description: New Orleans and the Caribbean connections through colonization, slavery, modernity, legacies of race, gender and class, the expressive arts.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.Term Offered: Spring (even years).

name: Gender Equity in Development
description: Course Description: Various forms of women's power, and potentials for disempowerment within the context of international development.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Offered as an online course only.

name: Development and Empowerment
description: Course Description: Development as an economic process of wealth accumulation, as well as a socio-political process of empowerment.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Community Development from the Ground Up
description: Course Description: Participatory methods in the monitoring and evaluation of development projects, where multiple stakeholders are involved in the process.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Hunter-Gatherer Ecology
description: Course Description: Development of anthropological method and theory; study of contemporary and prehistoric foraging peoples.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 and ANTH 120 and ANTH 121 and ANTH 140.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Andean Archaeology and Ethnohistory
description: Course Description: Prehistory and colonial experiences of native Andean peoples.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 or ANTH 140.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).

name: Archaeology of Mesoamerica
description: Course Description: Ancient cultures and civilizations in Middle America.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Impacts on Ancient Environments
description: Course Description: Major issues and case studies in the archaeology of ancient human societies and their environmental impacts.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Anthropological Perspectives on Food
description: Course Description: A long term perspective on the political economy of human food ways from ancient hunter-gatherers to the present. Topics will include foraging practices, domestication, feasting and emergent social complexity, the role of food in ancient states, and globalization, as well as the modern food economy. Lectures and readings will be based on research in archaeology, cultural anthropology, and biological anthropology.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 and ANTH 120 or ANTH 100 and ANTH 140 or ANTH 100 and ANTH 200 or ANTH 120 and ANTH 140 or ANTH 120 and ANTH 200 or ANTH 140 and ANTH 200.
column11: Registration Information: Junior standing.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Great Plains Archaeology
description: Course Description: Prehistoric people on Great Plains from earliest hunter-gatherers to historic contact; cultural responses to changing conditions.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.Term Offered: Fall (even years).
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Archaeology and the Public
description: Course Description: Applied archaeology in public settings, including publication, museum display, education, the illicit artifact trade, and other ethical issues.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  (ANTH 140) and (ANTH 252 or ANTH 350 or ANTH 351 or ANTH 352 or ANTH 451 or ANTH 452 or ANTH 453 or ANTH 455 or ANTH 460 or ANTH 465).
column11: Registration Information: 3 additional credits of archaeology required. Required field trips.Term Offered: Spring (even years).

name: Lithic Technology
description: Course Description: Method and theory behind production, use, and discard of stone tools by prehistoric peoples. Hands-on application in laboratory setting.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.
column11: Registration Information: Must register for lecture and laboratory.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).

name: Archaeology and Cultural Resource Management
description: Course Description: Cultural Resource Management as a career, the network of regulations that form the backbone of the industry, and the process for conducting a CRM investigation as an archaeologist. Topics include cultural resource legislation, project planning, execution, management, client communications, site analysis and evaluation, effects determinations, and agency and tribal consultations. Topical issues including case studies and industry trends will be explored.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 100 to 499 - at least 6 credits.
column11: Registration Information: Offered as an online course only.

name: Gods, Heroes, Stones--Greek Archaeology
description: Course Description: Explores the broad anthropological trends of the archaeology of Ancient Greece. Approaches this world via important archaeological topics that contextualize the historical, religious, economic, and socio-political trends, influences, and impetuses to come to a holistic understanding of what it meant to be an ancient Greek from c. 3000 to 31 BCE.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Field Class in Archaeology
description: Course Description: Directed fieldwork in local archaeology, site survey, and excavation; recovery, preservation, cataloging, analysis of artifactual and skeletal materials.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Registration Information: Written consent of instructor. Required field trips.Term Offered: Summer.

name: Anthropological Report Preparation
description: Course Description: Producing written and oral presentations for anthropological research, employment, or graduate work. Grant writing and manuscript preparation.

name: Anthropology Curation and Exhibition Methods
description: Course Description: Current methods and ethics in museum curation, conservation, collections management policies and procedures, exhibition development, and other tasks associated with managing, preserving and displaying anthropological collections (both artifacts and their associated documentation). Practical, hands-on experience in artifact care, management, preservation, and exhibition development.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must not be a: Freshman.
column11: Registration Information: Sophomore standing. 3 credits of ANTH or ART or HIST. Sections may be offered: Online.Term Offered: Spring.

name: Zooarchaeology
description: Course Description: Analysis of animal bones from archaeological sites to develop interpretations of past human behavior.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 and ANTH 140.
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.
column11: Registration Information: Must register for lecture and laboratory.Term Offered: Spring (odd years).

name: Archaeology of the Ancient Near East
description: Course Description: Explores the broad anthropological trends of the archaeology of the Ancient Near East. Approaches this world via important archaeological topics that contextualize the historical, religious, economic, and socio-political trends, influences, and impetuses to come to a holistic understanding of what it meant to be a Mesopotamian from c. 5000 to 323 BCE.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.
column11: Registration Information: Sections may be offered: Online.

name: Paleontology Field School
description: Course Description: Field methods in fossil excavation, preservation, and curation; the evolution of the primate order.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 110 or LIFE 102.
column11: Registration Information: Required field trips.Term Offered: Summer.

name: Human Biology
description: Course Description: Human biological responses to environmental conditions and constraints including diet, nutrition, disease, climate, culture change, and urbanization.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 120 or BZ 110 or LIFE 102.Term Offered: Spring (odd years).

name: The Neandertals
description: Course Description: Socio-historical foundations of questions regarding Neandertal paleobiology and culture and the Neandertal role in the evolution of Homo sapiens.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  (ANTH 120 or BZ 110) and (ANTH 372 or ANTH 373 or ANTH 374 or ANTH 375 or ANTH 376).Term Offered: Spring (even years).

name: Human Skeleton Analysis
description: Course Description: Focus on methods and techniques used to reconstruct identity and behavior from the human skeleton applicable to all areas of skeletal biology, including bioarchaeology, paleoanthropology, and forensic anthropology.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  (ANTH 120 or BZ 101) and (ANTH 372).
column11: Registration Information: Senior standing. Must register for lecture and laboratory.Term Offered: Spring.

name: Methods of Analysis in Paleoanthropology
description: Course Description: Practical discussion of techniques used to reconstruct dietary and locomotor behavior and evolutionary relationships in human fossil remains.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 373.Term Offered: Fall (even years).

name: The Archaeology of Time
description: Course Description: Concepts, methods, and techniques in the study of archaeological temporalities and chronology building. Examination of major themes running through the current social science literature on notions of time.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 140.
column11: Registration Information: Junior standing. Credit not allowed for both ANTH 476 and ANTH 480A4.

name: Heritage Resource Management
description: Course Description: Cultural resource laws and policy; practices commonly employed in management and preservation of these diverse resources.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: .
column11: Also Offered As:  HIST 478.
column12: Registration Information: Junior or senior standing.  Credit not allowed for both ANTH 478 and HIST 478.Term Offered: Spring (even years).

name: International Development Theory and Practice
description: Course Description: Contemporary issues in international community and economic development, with practical and theoretical analysis from interdisciplinary perspectives.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must be a: Junior, Senior, Senior - 5yr Bachelor, Senior - Post Bachelor, Senior - Second Bachelor.
column11: Also Offered As:  IE 479.
column12: Registration Information: Junior or senior standing. Credit not allowed for both ANTH 479 and IE 479.Term Offered: Fall.

name: A  Study Abroad: Communities and Conservation in South Africa
description: Course Description: Travel to the wildest areas of savanna South Africa to work and learn from rural and urbanizing communities. Insights into the innovative forms of community-based natural resource management emerging in South Africa. Understand the new landscapes of conservation associated with post-apartheid South Africa. Explore the problems faced by the millions of people living in poverty at the edge of protected areas.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Also Offered As:  ESS 482A.
column12: Registration Information: Written consent of instructor. Pre-South Africa: during the spring semester prior to the actual study abroad experience, students will meet in March and April for workshops and guest lectures on the CSU campus. In South Africa: travel approximately June 10 – July 2. Post-South Africa: students and instructors will schedule 20 hours of consulting time while students work on group projects over 6 weeks. Credit not allowed for both ANTH 482A and ESS 482A.Term Offered: Summer.

prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.

prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.

name: Development of Anthropological Theory
description: Course Description: Contemporary development of anthropological thought.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must not be a: Undergraduate.
column11: Registration Information: Undergraduates must have written consent of instructor.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Psychiatric Anthropology Laboratory  Credit
description: Course Description: Use tools from psychiatric anthropology to construct culturally-sensitive scales for assessing mental health and subjective well-being. Mixed qualitative and quantitative methods, including using field observations, interviews, and surveys to build and assess well-being measures. Emphasis on collaborative group research and hands-on training involving field research and data collection and analysis via appropriate software packages.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 543, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 545, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 546, may be taken concurrently. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate.
column11: Registration Information: Graduate standing. Repeatable for credit.

name: Cultural Analysis of Qualitative Data  Credit
description: Course Description: Analysis of qualitative data such as ethnographic field-notes and interviews for cultural content. Topics include: theme analysis, cultural models analysis, grounded theory, and content analysis. Synthesizes inductive, deductive, and abductive approaches to the analysis of qualitative data. Emphasis on practical hands-on training of data collection and analysis techniques in a collaborative research setting, including practice using relevant software.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 543, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 545, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 546, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 547, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 566, may be taken concurrently. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate.

name: Cognitive Anthropology Field Methods  Credit
description: Course Description: Using structured interview methods developed in cognitive anthropology for understanding the cultural influence on human thinking, experience, and behavior. Covered elicitation techniques include: free-lists, pile-sorts, and cultural consensus and consonance forms of analysis. Emphasis on gaining practical hands-on training in cognitive anthropological data collection and analysis techniques in a collaborative research setting, including practice using relevant software.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 543, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 545, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 546, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 547, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 566, may be taken concurrently. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate.

name: Cultural Analysis of Personal Networks  Credit
description: Course Description: Using personal network research techniques to understand the cultural shaping of human connection, behavior, and experience. Practical hands-on training in personal network research techniques in a collaborative research setting, including experience with various data collection and analysis techniques, practice using relevant software, and theory building related to individual and collaborative group projects. Emphasis on anthropological perspectives and applications.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH 543, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 545, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 546, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 547, may be taken concurrently or ANTH 566, may be taken concurrently. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate.

name: Resilience, Well-Being, and Social Justice
description: Course Description: Concepts of resilience, well-being, and social justice in the context of a rapidly changing planet. These concepts are rarely integrated yet each is understood to help diagnose, measure, and solve global-scale problems. Engagement with many views from many fields, including the anthropological lens of a community-level scale, cross-cultural comparison, and holistic analyses.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate, Graduate cooperative program.
column11: Registration Information: Graduate standing.Term Offered: Spring.

name: Anthropology of Happiness and the Good Life
description: Course Description: Draws on anthropological and interdisciplinary perspectives to illuminate the sociocultural and evolutionary basis of human happiness and flourishing. Examination of anthropological approaches to value, morality, and social norms; economic, environmental, and social determinants of happiness; sources of human resilience, including religion and play; happiness over the life course; emotions and subjective well-being; biological and health correlates of happiness.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate.Term Offered: Spring (even years).

name: Culture and Environment
description: Course Description: Theoretical accounts of societies' variable relationships to their environments, indigenous peoples' interactions with nature in context of modernity.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Registration Information: Graduate standing.Term Offered: Fall.

name: Women, Health, and Culture
description: Course Description: Women's experiences and interpretations of their health; cultural, political, and economic forces affecting women's health.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate, Graduate cooperative program, Professional.
column11: Registration Information: Graduate standing.Term Offered: Spring (odd years).

name: Gender, Sexuality, and Culture
description: Course Description: Gender and sexuality cross-culturally; theory, cultural constructions, colonialism, class, race, ethnicity, health, violence.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must not be a: Undergraduate.
column11: Registration Information: Graduate standing.Term Offered: Spring (even years).

prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH - at least 9 credits.Term Offered: Spring.

name: The Culture of Disaster
description: Course Description: Study of how the human impacts of disaster and the process of recovery are shaped by cultural as well as structural realities.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
column11: Registration Information: Graduate standing.Term Offered: Spring.

name: Globalization and Culture Change
description: Course Description: Evolving paradigms and patterns of globalization and international development; cultural responses -- resistance, dependency, fragmented identities.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  ANTH - at least 9 credits.Term Offered: Fall (even years).
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.

name: Food, Hunger, and Culture
description: Course Description: Explores cultural and social understandings of food cross-culturally, including the symbolic meanings that people attribute to food and its consumption. Critically investigates the intersecting political, economic, social, and cultural influences on hunger, malnutrition, and other health concerns associated with food and nutrition globally. Assesses applied anthropological approaches to reducing hunger and other nutrition related health problems.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate, Graduate cooperative program.
column11: Registration Information: Graduate standing. Credit not allowed for both ANTH 538 or ANTH 581A2.

name: Anthropology of Modernity
description: Course Description: Critical examination of the institutions, values, and processes which constitute the modern world. Impact of modern forces on "traditional" peoples.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None.
gradeMode: Grade Modes:  S/U within Student Option, Trad within Student Option.
column11: Registration Information: Graduate standing.Term Offered: Fall (odd years).

name: Medical Anthropology

prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate, Graduate cooperative program, Professional.

name: Foundations of Ethnographic Research
description: Course Description: Mixed qualitative and quantitative field methods to address practical real-world issues. Emphasis on linking theory and method, project formulation, hands-on experience with data collection and analysis, and practical applications such as preparing thesis/dissertation proposals and writing grants. Discussion of a range of anthropological approaches to field research, including applied, public, collaborative, participatory, and community-based ethnographic research.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate, Graduate cooperative program.

Classical theory alongside contemporary texts that revise or revisit early works. Focus on some major theories and themes that are important in cultural anthropology since the 1960s.

name: Geoarchaeology
description: Course Description: Application of analytical techniques, concepts, and field methods drawn from the earth sciences to help solve archaeological problems. Issues explored include human and environmental processes involved in archaeological site formation, the sedimentary context of archaeological remains, soils and sediments relevant to archaeology, the relationship between past settlement and landscape evolution, paleoclimatic reconstruction, and human effects on the environment.
prerequisite: Prerequisite:  None. Restriction: Must be a: Graduate.

An interdisciplinary approach to studying the ways biological, material, historical, political-economic and cultural processes combine to shape human-environment relationships in place-based contexts.

description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary thinking on questions of place, power, embodiment, and environmental adaptation. Drawing on human geography, ethnography, political ecology, and social-ecological theory, develop an understanding of boundaries and transitional zones as places of complex social and species exchange by looking at some key philosophical texts, but also applying theoretical understanding to specific case studies.
